entry.title: What is the most offended you've ever been?
entry.content:
What is the most offended youâ€™ve ever been?

Elizabeth Sabella, Former Retired school district administrator at Bristol Township School

302k Views Â· 8.6k Upvotes

About 40 years ago, my mother suggested I send my 10 year old son to my sisterâ€™s house for the summer. Mom believed that grandson needed to be â€œstraightened outâ€. I was crushed to think I wasnâ€™t an adequate mother in her eyes.

My parents approved of my sisterâ€™s style of child-rearing. She had 4 daughters that she potty trained in 1 day with a wooden spoon. They ran diaper free all day, then when they relieved themselves, she hit them with the spoon and sat them on the pot. She carried that spoon everywhere she went, and had no problem hitting them wherever and whenever they misbehaved. Her primary goal was obedience.

I allowed my kids to express their feelings, but made it clear that they still had to do what I told them to do. My family thought my kids were undisciplined and that I was unable to control them.

I refused to follow their child rearing methods, and I was comfortable with my style. I am proud of the fine men my sons turned out to be, and happy that they grew up knowing that their feelings were valid, and they were heard.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Michelle A Rivera

Iâ€™m a dog trainer and when you wrote about how she let them run around all day with no pants and then hit them I was horrified. But, I let my two sons run around with just a long t-shirt on and whenever they started to pee I picked them up and put them on the little potty. I really didnâ€™t think it was a bad way to potty train. But positive reinforcement is powerful and when they finally got the concept they got praise and a sticker. Itâ€™s how I trained puppies, and itâ€™s the only way I knew how. The point is to catch them in the act and show them the proper place to do that. It worked pretty well.

entry.title: What are some unwritten social rules everyone should know?
entry.content:
What are some unwritten social rules everyone should know?

Alex Ferman, Passionate Writer, CA (2013 - present)

292.6k Views Â· 6.7k Upvotes

  1. 1+1 = 3 if you donâ€™t use the condom.

  2. Alcohol increase size of the â€œSENDâ€ button by 89%.

  3. Never underestimate the power of stupid people in large groups.

  4. Sometimes we create our own heartbreaks through expectations.

  5. Life is too short to be with the wrong person.

  6. Just because you love them, it doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re right for you.

  7. Feelings that come back are feelings that never left.

  8. Everythingâ€™s not as easy as getting fat.

  9. Even a bad day is just 24 hours.

  10. Itâ€™s not your job to fix people.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Littlebigmous

Be kind and be niceâ€¦ but do not expect others to treat you in the same way. We all have our demons. If you encounter someone who is entangled with their demons, be nice to yourself as it is not your battle to fight and walk away.

entry.title: How do I make my 14-year-old son more manly?
entry.content:
How do I make my 14-year-old son more manly?

Chris Clarke, Studying ancient Hebrew

1.3M Views Â· 1.1k Upvotes

By being one yourself (sigh).

This type of question triggers me, mainly because my dadâ€™s focus was the same thing, but yet he never taught me anything because he was never taught how to be more manly. So he expected me to be it, yet what child can learn without a template, what apprentice can learn without a teacher, lest the apprentice goes down the wrong path and find another teacher who teaches them the wrong way.

Become secure in yourself, talk to him, your wife, your friends, your family, your neighbors, your coworkers, your communities and everyone under the sun the way you want your son to. And I promise you, you donâ€™t have to say a single word to your son, he will see you are successful and mirror you, because heâ€™ll want to receive the blessing that are receiving down this path.

And tell him the truthâ€¦ youâ€™re learning how to do it as well, and youâ€™ll figure it out together - like father and son.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Rupert Cheek

and LISTEN (to him)!

entry.title: What makes you feel grateful?
entry.content:
What makes you feel grateful?

Inam Tanveer Talks, Former Medical officer

64.5k Views Â· 5.9k Upvotes

The rich industrialist was horrified to find the fisherman Iying beside his boat, smoking a pipe.

â€˜Why arenâ€™t you out fishing?â€™ asked the industrialist.

â€˜Because I have caught enough fish for the day.â€™

â€˜Why donâ€™t you catch some more?â€™

â€˜What would I do with them?â€™

â€˜You could earn more money. Then you could have a motor fitted to your boat to go into deeper waters and catch more fish. Then you would have enough money to buy nylon nets. These would bring you more fish and more money. Soon you would have enough money own two boatsâ€¦maybe even a fleet of boats. Then you would be a rich man like me.â€™

â€˜What would I do then?â€™

â€˜Then you could sit back and enjoy life.â€™

â€˜What do you think Iâ€™m doing right now?â€™

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Brian Mead

This is my attitude towards work. Why would I ever think myself poor? I am content with what I have, I am fed, sheltered, and so on. I have things I enjoy, and I have people who truly care about me. I am not poor in any measure.

entry.title: What is the biggest lie society has taught you to believe?
entry.content:
What is the biggest lie society has taught you to believe?

Hector Quintanilla

411.9k Views Â· 7.8k Upvotes

LIE: â€œWork hard and youâ€™ll achieve financial freedom.â€

Yes, itâ€™s a popular belief that hard work pays off.

And it does.

In fact, hard work is non-negotiable.

Butâ€¦ thereâ€™s a LIMIT to hard work.

We all have the same 24 hours in a day, and I can guarantee you will meet these limits EVERY single day.

But, if Jeff Bezos grew his net worth by $75 billion in 2020 â€” does that mean he worked 1,000,000 X harder than someone making $75K a year?

Obviously no!

So yes, thereâ€™s hard work, but hard work will always face our human limitations. Then, thereâ€™s smart work, where there are no boundaries!

If youâ€™ve hit the â€œroofâ€ of hard work, you will only find further growth until you change HOW you work.

LIE: Work hard and youâ€™ll achieve financial freedom.

Yes, work hard, but stop trying to â€œworkâ€ your way to wealth.

Financial success is found in working smarter and that is only found through the experience and wisdom of others.

Leveraging other peopleâ€™s knowledge is your shortcut to make a good living.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Quinn Copeland:

â€œWork hardâ€ is meant to reference putting in effort, not long hours of manual labor. The point is that its not enough to have a good idea, you have to be focused and put the work in to execute it.

entry.title: Why can't we collect CO2 from the atmosphere, break it down in a lab and just release the O2 back in order to slow climate change?
entry.content:
Why canâ€™t we collect CO2 from the atmosphere, break it down in a lab and just release the O2 back in order to slow climate change?

Andy Duffell, Armourer, engineer, nerd.Dec 27

45k Views Â· 6k Upvotes

We can, here is a picture of the machine we would use for that job:

This machine is built from self-organising nanomachines, can self-repair and self-replicate, requires little to no maintenance, is solar powered and both converts CO2 to O2 and also sequesters atmospheric carbon within itself. It also acts as habitat for wildlife!

Itâ€™s a technological marvel thatâ€™s the result of billions of years of R&D, and the best thing is that itâ€™s available now and itâ€™s dirt cheap.

Honestly, what do you think we could do in a lab which even comes close to this incredible biomachine?

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Geoff Caplan:
Unfortunately if you do the math, this wonderful machine can only play a marginal role in saving our planet for human habitation. We want as many of them as possible for a host of good reasons, but itâ€™s important not to over-hype their potential and divert attention from higher impact policies.

entry.title: What am I missing out on in life if I don't have a girlfriend?
entry.content:
What am I missing out on in life if I donâ€™t have a girlfriend?

Kelly Erickson, Experience Designer. Research hound. Constantly curious.

601.6k Views Â· 12.1k Upvotes

Depends entirely on the girlfriend. Some things you might be missing out on:

  • Soft smells from her hair, her skin, her extra set of clothes that she leaves in your closet
  • Hugs, peekaboo-guess-who, kisses on the back of your neck when youâ€™re hard at work and forgot about the world around you for too long
  • Good cooking, or maybe good-morning coffee, or good takeout
  • Inspiration, shared jokes, mind-bending middle-of-the-night discussions
  • A buddy whoâ€™ll hand you a tissue during the sad parts of your favorite moviesâ€¦ you know when Bruce Willis died in that one, you got all choked up, didnâ€™t ya?
  • An enthusiastic fan of your career, your writing, your sense of humor, your (terrible) saxophone playing, your pickup games of basketball on Saturday mornings
  • A convert to your football teamâ€¦ at least on the weeks when her fav team isnâ€™t playing yours
  • New music you didnâ€™t know about
  • Someone to tell about that new song you just heardâ€¦ even if itâ€™s kinda cheesy sheâ€™ll probably give it a try
  • Stories of her life before you
  • Someone to brag to, who loves listening to you brag
  • Whispered sweet nothings
  • A helper when you need a hand
  • Someone to helpâ€”who shows her appreciation in wild and wonderful ways, like cake when itâ€™s not your birthday
  • Tons of new experiences, new places to go, new foods to try, new friends to learn about, new authors and artists to consider, new lingerie to appreciate
  • Someone to grow into and grow comfortable with
  • Someone to tell secrets toâ€¦ good ones and bad onesâ€¦ without judgment
  • Tickling
  • Teasing
  • Phone calls when your boss isnâ€™t within earshot
  • Texts when ur boss isnâ€™t looking
  • A hand to hold, and arms to hold you, when times are tough and youâ€™re not sure you can support your own weight any more
  • A perspective very different from your own, but meltingly familiar
  • Butterflies in your stomach
  • The gentle jealousy of being in a secure relationship with someone whoâ€™s a â€œcatchâ€ in your eyesâ€”yet your eyes are the only ones that count to her
  • Massages
  • Caressing
  • French kisses
  • Spooning
  • Someone to be insanely, animalistically, proud of at all times
  • Someone to be insanely, animalistically, protective of at all times
  • Someone to be insane and animalistic with. At any time. ;)

entry.title: When did you know your parents were one of the good ones?
entry.content:
When did you know your parents were one of the good ones?

Jean-Marie ValheurÂ , married, father of threeDec 4

792.6k Views Â· 20.1k Upvotes

When I went to the house of my richest friend. I was in elementary school at the time. The boyâ€™s family lived in an enormous mansion. It was grand. It was glorious. Every nook and cranny of that building seemed to exude power, wealth, success. Walking up to the main door, I was utterly in awe of the size ofâ€¦ everything.

Then I went inside. And it wasâ€¦ empty. Not literally empty, there were chairs, sofas, the largest television set I had ever seen and some lamps. But the house had no books. The house had few pictures. And there were no parents to be seen.

I asked were my friendsâ€™ father was? At work, the answer went. He was always at work. His mother was â€œsickâ€, on bed with a headache.

Every time I was there, and I was there five or six times, dad was away at work, mom was sick with a headache. Looking back Iâ€™m almost certain the woman was an alcoholic. The man a workaholic. My friend was raised more or less by his older siblings.

Our house was small. Our families deeply involved. Life was simpleâ€¦ but it felt full. Theirs, though outwardly grand, felt empty. Just visiting that eery house a handful of times reminded me of how good I had it.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Edie:

My favorite place to live while growing up was with my Grandmother. She had a small barely 1,200 ft farmette w/1 bathroom. Many of my aunts and uncles (5 of them) still lived at home and a cousin who was my age also lived with her. The house was crowded, loud and full of love, laughs and great food. It was absolute bliss for me.

Jean-Marie Valheur:

I feel you! My own grandparentsâ€™ home, too, was a magical place. It was big. But full. So many items, so many photos, so many artifacts, each with their own unique story. There were always people going in and out, neighbors dropping by, uncles visiting, cousins parking the bikes in the drive way and relaxing in the sun in the garden behind their houseâ€¦ a magical place, a grandparentsâ€™ home. Donâ€™t know how that works. It somehow just is.

entry.title: What is the biggest life lesson you have ever learned?
entry.content:
What is the biggest life lesson you have ever learned?

Reven Lee, M.S. in Psychology & Consulting, The Ohio State University (Graduated 2017)

74.7k Views Â· 1.4k Upvotes

  1. Most people wonâ€™t support you until they see itâ€™s popular to support you.

  2. When making any major life decision, remember: If itâ€™s not a â€œFxck Yesâ€, then itâ€™s a â€œNo.â€

  3. You are not supposed to be the same person you were a year, month, day, or even five seconds ago. You are designed to grow.

  4. The most powerful way to win an argument is by asking questions. It can make people see the flaws in their logic.

  5. Just because you donâ€™t share it on social media, doesnâ€™t mean youâ€™re not up to big things.

  6. Live it and stay low key. Privacy is everything.

  7. One manâ€™s â€˜nah you require too muchâ€™ is another manâ€™s â€˜thatâ€™s all you need?â€™ Donâ€™t settle. You can find better ones.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Christian Bohn:

#1 is so powerful, so donâ€™t forget people who helped you when you were a nobody.

entry.title: I forgot to scan my one banana from Walmart and I realized it after I came home. Do I go back? Will I get in trouble?
entry.content:
I forgot to scan my one banana from Walmart and I realized it after I came home. Do I go back? Will I get in trouble?

John K Williamsson, Lives in United Federation of Planets (1951â€“present)Updated Dec 12

4M Views Â· 5.8k Upvotes

May I make a suggestion that will help the environment?

Call the store on the phone and apologize, say that you noticed when you got home that one banana did not get scanned.

Ask if you can pay for that banana the next time you are in the store.

I bet the manager tells you to forget about it.

personal anecdote

One time I was at Piggly Wiggly for one item. After getting the syrup, I realized I didnâ€™t have my wallet. I asked a manager who knew me by name if I could take it and pay for it the next day. He was happy to give me permission.

The next day, I went to a register, asked them to ring me up for the syrup without my having it there. She did. I showed the receipt to Mr. Rogers, yes thatâ€™s his name, and he smiled.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

S Hosain:
While in college, a friend and I bought a bunch of items at a supermarket to make dinner for about 6 or 7 people. After we left to walk back, I glanced at the bill and realized that it was way too low.

The cashier had scanned everything in front of us - we heard the beeps and tones, etc., but many items just had not made it to the total. As I recall, we had been undercharged about 30% to 40%.

We walked back and spoke to the manager. After he realized that we were not complaining about being overcharged or that the cashier was making errors (we were very clear about that!), he went over the register and realized that it wasnâ€™t working properly. I guess many people had paid less than they should have - certainly that day!

He shut the register down, thanked us, and waved us out! As college students with a tight budget, this certainly helped the dinner cost out for all of us!

Honesty is the right approach.

entry.title: What should we do?
entry.content:
My teenager wants only an Apple phone. We tried to explain that we canâ€™t afford it, and she stopped speaking with us. What should we do?

Tawni Doliveira

659.9k Views Â· 2.7k Upvotes

When I was 7, I was diagnosed with Type 1 Diabetes. I was in 2nd grade. My mom decided to get me a flip phone through Tracfone to text her if my blood sugar drops or if the nurse doesnâ€™t show up to give me my insulin dose.

Every other year after that I got a new Tracfone for Christmas. When I turned 12 or 13, I asked my mom for a newer, better phone. I had just moved to the high school (7th-12th grade) and everyone else had nice iPhones. I knew my mom couldnâ€™t afford an iPhone so I searched eBay for any phone that would do more than a cheap Tracfone.

At my school, teachers allow students to use a phone to search things, take pictures of dissections or powerpoints, or do our online assignments. I wanted to be able to be like everyone else and not have to go to get a teacher to unlock the room to the laptops to be able to do what others do or have to use a dictionary and have homework because it took too long to find the definitions.

I found a cheap android phone by the company Blu and my mom bought it for me. I loved it. My mom couldnâ€™t afford data so I used the schoolâ€™s WiFi.

About 2 years later, I wanted an iPhone. I got bullied for being poor and having a phone that became slow and was considered cheap. My mom got me a refurbished iPhone 6s Plus for Christmas 2016. Iâ€™m still using this phone and I love it.

Yes, Iâ€™d LOVE to have the newest iPhone but Iâ€™m very thankful to have this phone. My family hasnâ€™t had an income for 4 years yet my mom figured out a way to get me a better phone that would last a while.

Iâ€™m NOT telling you that this is what you should do. What Iâ€™m saying is ask her why she thinks she needs an iPhone. Ask her why she feels that way. Try to compromise with her. But hear her out. Teenagers often feel as if their feelings are invalid and that we donâ€™t have good points.

Have a conversation, donâ€™t yell or raise your voice or have an attitude that screams â€œIâ€™m better than you and only my points and views are validâ€. It makes us more angry because our side of the conversation isnâ€™t being heard.

All Iâ€™m saying is listen to her. Everything will work out â¤ï¸

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Cris Brisbin:
Find one Used or refurbishedâ€¦ lower modelâ€¦ etcâ€¦ it doesnt have to be the X

entry.title: What are the simplest things one can do to make oneself happier?
entry.content:
What are the simplest things one can do to make oneself happier?

Brad Einarsen, social marketer, insights collector, Written Nov 8, 2012 Â· Featured in Lifehacker

178k Views Â· 61.3k Upvotes

When I was in a dark period I instituted a simple rule that changed my life.

Rule:
When I arrive home from work, the very first thing I tell my wife is the best thing that happened that day.

No exceptions. No complaining. Just the best thing that day, even if it was just a good cup of coffee. This had the effect of starting our evening off on a positive note and it changed our relationship.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Nadav Gur:
Teach your kids to do this. Every day when you tuck them in have them tell you â€œwhatâ€™s the best thing that happened to you todayâ€. It may be the most important thing you teach them ever.

entry.title: Is it true that China is trying to change the climate in one of its regions? How and why?
entry.content:
Is it true that China is trying to change the climate in one of its regions? How and why?

Mila Lana, Lives in Bratsk, Siberia, RussiaDec 10

351.4k Views Â· 8.7k Upvotes

If you mean desert greening (as a result of which the climate inevitably changes to a more humid and less severe one), then yes - they do it, and they have success. The Mu-Us Desert is clear evidence:

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Henry Young:
China has come a long way in this effort. Back in 1983 in Hong Kong when I was working in an intl bank, I met a foreigner who came down from Gansu, he told me he was involved in desert greening there and we talked about the trees and plants used and some trial and experiments. From then to now it is almost about half a century.

â–Œè¯æ±‡:

  • humid: if the weather is humid, you feel uncomfortable because the air is very wet and usually hotã€”å¤©æ°”ã€•æ½®æ¹¿ï¼ˆç‚çƒ­ï¼‰çš„

entry.title: What was the best relationship advice you ever got?
entry.content:
What was the best relationship advice you ever got?

Zeeshan Mushtaq, Iâ€™m living. Learning. Discovering.

357.7k Views Â· 12.3k Upvotes

A big, big thank you to my ex for showering me with these beautiful pieces of advice.

  • Never date someone youâ€™re not attracted to. If youâ€™re confused, itâ€™s a NO.
  • Never date someone who has recently come out of a break-up. He/She might be on a rebound. In fact, in most of the cases, they are.
  • Never date someone whoâ€™s not emotionally strong as you. Youâ€™ll be the one to suffer.
  • Donâ€™t rush things. Rushing things will only lead to more complications. Start slow. Discover each other.
  • If your partner has lied to you on small things, he/she is capable of lying to you on more big things as well. Immediately leave them.
  • Lack of communication destroys a relationship. Always communicate about your problems with your partner. Try to sort them out.
  • And lastly, donâ€™t confuse lust with love.

Peace

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Neil Barembaum:
I would add two more, just as basic as these. Never date someone who is with someone else, even if they are willing to leave them for you â€” especially if they leave them for you. If they leave them for you, they will leave you for the next person.
Never date someone because you think it is your last chance. There will always be another.

https://www.quora.com/What-was-the-best-relationship-advice-you-ever-got/answer/Zeeshan-Mushtaq-5
entry.summary: Never date someone you're not attracted to. If you're confused, it's a NO. Never date someone who has recently come out of a break-up. He/She might be on a rebound. In fact, in most of the cases, they are. Never date someone who's not emotionally strong as you. You'll be the one to suffer.

319.7k Views Â· 39.2k Upvotes

What a broad thinking a Mother has for her neighbors!â€¦ Salute to her for kind Heart she hasâ€¦ğŸ‘ Everybody should help people around them; so this world could become a better place for allâ€¦ ğŸ™‚

I would do something similar in school. Being one of the more gifted students, people naturally came to me for help with stuff.

In return, I would ask for help in other topics they would excel in (Though I needed no real help) to balance it a little.

entry.title: How do married people stay in love with their spouse when they are old, wrinkled, and grey?
entry.content:
How do married people stay in love with their spouse when they are old, wrinkled, and grey?

Terry Melvin, Lives in Tacoma, WA (1953â€“present)10mo

1.2M Views Â· 33.9k Upvotes

Let me answer this with my own anecdote.

My wife has had medical problems that have caused her to lose her figure. She is now very thin and wrinkled, and in the past year sheâ€™s lost all her teeth. She has dentures but usually wonâ€™t wear them when sheâ€™s at home.

Weâ€™ve been together for just short of 41 years now.

Anyway, one day she was sitting on the couch folding clothes, so I sat down on the couch next to her and gathered her in my arms. That beautiful ( though toothless) smile was still there, as was the light in her eyes that has never dimmed.

And I held her and realized, â€œmy God I will always love this womanâ€.

And above all, in those eyes I saw that she feels the same about old, arthritic and wrinkled me.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Ken Simpson:
In my basement, I have a small metal lockable box. The kind that is typically used to keep cash in at garage sales.

In that box is a picture of my wife. She was 20 years old and worked in a supermarket. Back then cashiers wore white uniforms, similar to a nurseâ€™s outfit.

Anyhow, she is just standing, smiling, in her white dress. Thatâ€™s all. No sexy. Just standing, and smiling.

When I look at her now, 50 years later, thatâ€™s what I see. I swear, in my eyes she hasnâ€™t changed a bit.

I donâ€™t know how that works, but it does.

entry.title: What are ten truths everyone should accept in life?
entry.content:
What are ten truths everyone should accept in life?

Sherry Cam, Psychological Counselor(2014-present), LAJan 20

564.9k Views Â· 10k Upvotes

  1. If it doesnâ€™t open, itâ€™s not your door.
  2. Some days you need the music and some days you need the lyrics.
  3. If someone is stupid enough, then walk away from you, be smart enough to let them go.
  4. Making mistakes is better than faking perfections.
  5. Remember to learn your limits if you are givers.
  6. Itâ€™s better to lose someone instead of losing your mind.
  7. Kindness is not flirting.
    • Attention is not love.
    • Silence is not anger.
    • Tears is not a weakness.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Erwin Anciano:
My bathroom door got stuck once while I was inside. It wasnâ€™t my door, apparently.

Serbanescu Mihai:
Attention is love. You make time and put attention in/to the things that you love or people. Is like, I love you but I donâ€™t put attention in what you say. How this come?:)

Baltazar Avalos:
Yes, be present, be attentive to someone, is love

https://qr.ae/pGEXP0
entry.summary: It's better to lose someone instead of losing your mind. Kindness is not flirting. Attention is not love. Silence is not anger. Tears is not a weakness.

entry.title: What are 10 things that you should definitely do before turning 30?
entry.content:
What are 10 things that you should definitely do before turning 30?

Lavanya, Knows TeluguUpdated 2y

250.9k Views Â· 2.8k Upvotes

  1. Marriage is just a part of life.
  2. Being single is Normal thing.
  3. Before entering into Relationship , financial independence is must ,specially for girls.
  4. Dont downgrade any girl for being single even near by 30s.
  5. Dont measure salary to give respect to Guys.
  6. Purchasing a car is a liability, owning site is appreciating asset.
  7. If you have 10 lakhs and are thinking about purchasing of a Car , go for purchasing agricuture land in near by small village instead.
  8. Instead of purchasing Car ,go for Cab, mostly it costs less than maintainace fee of Car per Month.
  9. If your sister wants to study further, let her please.
  10. Dont depend tooo much on your spouse.
  11. Household chores is basic thing , every body should learn and do.
  12. Do have Driving License.
  13. Invest in Liquid funds which you can get liquadated in urgency easily.
  14. Government job is not compulsory.
  15. Dont take Relatives so seriously , the demotivating relatives are passing clouds.
  16. Love making is different from having Sex, if your partner forced to have sex before Marriage Dont accept if you are not ready emotionally.
  17. Take a journey with yourself to New places.
  18. Show emotional attachements to only very very closed ones.
  19. Dont make other people to accept your past, you are right at that situations in your own way.
  20. You are not tooo old.
  21. At this stage , most of the parents get Health issues , take Health Insurance.
  22. If you are not satisfied with your Job, try to do online Business ( Flipkart, Amazon ) by selling local products which is famous in your Home town.
  23. Happiness does not come on a particular day or date or after fulfilling a particular wish, it just lies in oneâ€™s mind, try to be happy everyday. Becuase we dont know when we will die.

â–Œè¯„è®º:

Kusum Motiani:
I am in my 40s now and I purchased car when I was in 30s. Today my car gives me the independence of taking my children wherever they want. An agricultural land would not have given happiness to my children. I think advises should be followed depending on your situationsâ€¦ What will I do with driving license if I donâ€™t have a car and not going to drive it. I just love driving and cannot imagine a day without my carâ€¦:-)

https://qr.ae/pGB09X
entry.summary: 1. Marriage is just a part of life. 2. Being single is Normal thing. 3. Before entering into Relationship , financial independence is must ,specially for girls. 4. Dont downgrade any girl for being single even near by 30s. 5. Dont measure salary to give respect to Guys.
